{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3126205,"name":"NewtonCrosby","username":"NewtonCrosby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ed8c4c/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-14T17:40:43.804Z","cooked":"

We are trying to help our programmers understand unit testing as a functional skill. I thought unit testing our robot code would be a great platform to do that since it’s got built-in support. I have the tests properly building but the test predicates are not passing.

I threw the following into the FRC discord as well:
"Does anyone know of a team or code examples where they are able to “Test Robot Code” successfully with Falcons as the test target motor? I don’t find any unit testing in the CTRE examples, and my own Google skills are failing me. I was under the impression that Junit tests are running as a simulation, so I thought I’d be testing my predicates against the TalonFXSimCollection objects (which don’t have enough getters to be useful). So now I’m trying to just query the IntegratedSensor for velocity from the normal TalonFX objects and my velocities are all 0, when I’m expecting them to be non-zero.

I’m pretty much a Java neophyte, so I’m trying to wrap my head around how to run these tests in a Debugger but that’s a separate issue."

So, if there’s a team out there that has successfully unit tested a subsystem with TalonFX motor controllers it would be great to see your/their code if it’s public.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-01-14T17:40:43.804Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":127,"reads":223,"readers_count":222,"score":679.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":423124,"topic_slug":"need-advice-or-help-running-unit-tests-with-falcon500-motors","display_username":"NewtonCrosby","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31346,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/need-advice-or-help-running-unit-tests-with-falcon500-motors/423124/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3126231,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-14T18:20:48.357Z","cooked":"

Use either the simulation interface or Mockito to write a mock of your motor object that does what you want for testing purposes.

Relying heavily on simulator behavior in unit tests defeats the purpose of the unit tests; at that point you’re testing the simulator more than your own code. Remember that unit tests are supposed to verify the behavior of small independent pieces (“units”) of your code to a high degree of confidence. They are not supposed to verify the global soundness of your code - that’s the job of integration testing, which is often best-done on actual hardware.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-01-14T18:23:00.870Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":188,"readers_count":187,"score":47.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":423124,"topic_slug":"need-advice-or-help-running-unit-tests-with-falcon500-motors","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/need-advice-or-help-running-unit-tests-with-falcon500-motors/423124/2","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3126257,"name":"NewtonCrosby","username":"NewtonCrosby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ed8c4c/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-14T19:12:33.699Z","cooked":"

Thanks for the reply, I think my understanding of the WPILib docs were essentially doing just that.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Unit Testing

Unit testing is a method of testing code by dividing the code into the smallest “units” possible and testing each unit. In robot code, this can mean testing the code for each subsystem individually...

That example is using sim objects to represent the PWM motor, (effectively) mocking the actual motor controller object in the subsystem. I was hoping to do that, but with TalonFX controllers. May not be as simple with TalonFX and CAN.

I have heard of it, if it’s got a patching style function like Python mocks I can hopefully write up some training for the students to get it working in our codebase.

Phoenix simulation also simulates the CAN delay between the command being sent and it being applied. A delay such as Thread.sleep(100) should make it work. (Just be careful not to keep the delays in the real robot code.)

I clearly have no real understanding of how the simulation pieces work.

Our code with my test is here.

Can you take a look to see if you see what I’m missing. I was hoping to have a suite of tests to verify the basic functionality of the subsystems before we even get into debugging in the simulator (and then on the real robot).

So I’ve been reading their docs last night and today, and I’m not grokking how I can make this work in the Drivetrain testing.

If I mock a drive train with a void method like teleop_drive(), I think the mock objects (or stubs) that I really need to verify is that the TalonFX objects are being called with proper arguments. I don’t quite understand how to get inspection of those inner member variables.

Inside the teleop_drive method there’s a call to a static WPILib method and then passing those return values to the two Talon objects.

I’m thinking maybe agument capture may be the best route, trying to work that out now.

I thought that’s what I was already doing.

The dt.teleop_drive() is what is setting the motor commands, and then the sleeps exist before the asserts.

I tried sleeping up to 2 seconds to verify it wasn’t working.

EDIT TO ADD: Are you suggesting the sleeps go in the actual drive train method, not in the test case?

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-01-15T19:56:09.296Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":81,"readers_count":80,"score":26.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":423124,"topic_slug":"need-advice-or-help-running-unit-tests-with-falcon500-motors","display_username":"NewtonCrosby","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":45763,"username":"Starlight220","name":null,"avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starlight220/{size}/150872_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31346,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/need-advice-or-help-running-unit-tests-with-falcon500-motors/423124/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3126954,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-15T20:07:30.255Z","cooked":"

If I had to guess, the robot isn’t enabled during unit tests, so you’ll have to call Unmanaged.feedEnable(100) periodically to enable CTRE actuators. This is normally done automatically in simulation by the WPI_* classes while the robot is enabled, but if the robot isn’t enabled during unit tests, then the function has to be called manually. API documentation

For CTRE devices, my coworker @TytanRock and his team have some good unit test examples: Robot-2022/BallHandlingTests.java at main · De-La-Salle-Robotics/Robot-2022 (github.com)
Two things to note:

  1. Their waitForUpdate function replaces any Thread.sleep (or Task.delay from WPILib), instead sleeping in increments and feeding the enable signal for 100ms. I think the loop condition and the sleep are flipped in their code though, you should probably Thread.sleep(10) and loop for i < (long)(seconds * 100), otherwise long wait times may not feed the enable frequently enough.
  2. Most of these tests are not really testing the SimCollection object; that object is only really used in the simulationInit and simulationPeriodic functions to update simulated sensor values. Rather, most of the tests are testing the subsystems and the actual device objects and adding delays to take into account the simulated CAN frame timing.

Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-15T22:07:35.040Z","cooked":"

You want to mock the hardware dependencies only, not the entire drivetrain. So, you’d use Mockito to build a mock of the Talon class and check the interactions on that mock at the end of your test.

This may require adjusting your architecture to allow your drivetrain subsystem to have its motor controllers injected at runtime.
